1. Introduction
contents.ja: 1.はじめに

contents.text: This document discusses some existing commonly used BGP mechanisms for Autonomous System Number (ASN) migration that are not formally part of the BGP4 [RFC4271] protocol specification. These mechanisms are local to a given BGP speaker and do not require negotiation with or cooperation of BGP neighbors. The deployment of these mechanisms do not need to interwork with one another to accomplish the desired results, so slight variations between existing vendor implementations exist and will not necessarily be harmonized due to this document. However, it is necessary to document these de facto standards to ensure that new implementations can be successful, and any future protocol enhancements to BGP that propose to read, copy, manipulate, or compare the AS_PATH attribute can do so without inhibiting the use of these very widely used ASN migration mechanisms.
contents.ja: この文書では、正式にBGP4 [RFC4271]プロトコル仕様の一部ではない自律システム番号（ASN）の移行のためのいくつかの既存の一般的に使用されるBGPメカニズムを説明します。これらのメカニズムは、与えられたBGPスピーカーにローカルであり、との交渉やBGPネイバーの協力を必要としません。これらの機構の配置はこれ既存のベンダー実装間のわずかな変化が存在し、必ずしもこれによりドキュメントに調和されず、所望の結果を達成するために相互に連動する必要はありません。しかし、新しい実装が成功することを保証するために、これらのデファクトスタンダードを文書化する必要があり、かつ、読みコピー、操作、またはAS_PATH属性を比較することを提案するBGPへの将来のプロトコルの拡張機能は、これらの使用を阻害することなく行うことができます非常に広くASNの移行メカニズムを使用していました。

contents.text: The migration mechanisms discussed here are useful to ISPs and organizations of all sizes, but it is important to understand the business need for these mechanisms and illustrate why they are so critical for ISPs' operations. During a merger, acquisition, or divestiture involving two organizations it is necessary to seamlessly migrate both internal and external BGP speakers from one ASN to a second ASN. The overall goal in doing so is to simplify operations through consistent configurations across all BGP speakers in the combined network. In addition, given that the BGP Path Selection algorithm selects routes with the shortest AS_PATH attribute, it is critical that the ISP does not increase AS_PATH length during or after ASN migration, because an increased AS_PATH length would likely result in sudden, undesirable changes in traffic-patterns in the network.
contents.ja: ここで説明する移行メカニズムは、ISPやあらゆる規模の組織に有用であるが、これらのメカニズムのためのビジネスニーズを理解し、彼らはISPの操作のためにとても重要である理由を説明することが重要です。二つの組織が関与する合併、買収、または売却の際には、シームレスに二ASNに1つのASNから内部と外部の両方のBGPスピーカを移行する必要があります。そうすることで全体的な目標は、組み合わせネットワーク内のすべてのBGPスピーカ間で一貫性の構成を通じて操作を簡素化することです。また、BGPのパス選択アルゴリズムは、最短のAS_PATH属性を持つルートを選択したことを考えると、増加したAS_PATHの長さはおそらくトラフィックの急激な、望ましくない変化につながるので、ISPは、ASNの移行中または後にAS_PATHの長さを増加させないことが重要ですネットワークに-patterns。

contents.text: By default, the BGP protocol requires an operator to configure a router to use a single remote ASN for the BGP neighbor, and the ASN must match on both ends of the peering in order to successfully negotiate and establish a BGP session. Prior to the existence of these migration mechanisms, it would have required an ISP to coordinate an ASN change with, in some cases, tens of thousands of customers. In particular, as each router is migrated to the new ASN, to avoid an outage due to ASN mismatch, the ISP would have to force all customers on that router to change their router configurations to use the new ASN immediately after the ASN change. Thus, it was critical to define a more asymmetric migration method so that the ISP could seamlessly change the ASN within its network(s) but allow the customers to gradually migrate to the ISP's new ASN when convenient. These customer migrations could occur either by coordinating individual session reconfigurations or, to allow for truly asymmetric migration, by accepting sessions using either the old or new ASN.

contents.ja: 3.外部BGP自律システムの移行メカニズム

contents.text: The following section addresses optional capabilities that are specific to modifying the AS_PATH attribute at the Autonomous System Border Routers (ASBRs) of an organization (typically a single Service Provider). contents.text: 3.3. Implementation

The mechanisms introduced in this section MUST be configurable on a per-neighbor or per-neighbor-group basis to allow for maximum flexibility. (Here, "neighbor group" refers to a group of similar BGP neighbor statements that reuse some common configuration to simplify provisioning.) When the "Local AS" capability is used, a local ASN will be provided in the configuration that is different from the globally configured ASN of the BGP router. To implement this mechanism, a BGP speaker SHOULD send BGP OPEN [RFC4271] (see Section 4.2) messages to the configured eBGP peer(s) using the local ASN configured for this session as the value sent in "My Autonomous System". The BGP router SHOULD NOT use the ASN configured globally within the BGP process as the value sent in "My Autonomous System" in the OPEN message. This prevents causing the eBGP neighbor to unnecessarily generate a BGP OPEN Error message "Bad Peer AS". This method is typically used to re-establish eBGP sessions with peers expecting the legacy ASN after a router has been moved to a new ASN.

contents.text: 4.1. Internal BGP AS Migration

contents.text: In this case, all of the routers to be consolidated into a single, permanently retained ASN are under the administrative control of a single entity. Unfortunately, the traditional method of migrating all Internal BGP speakers, particularly within larger networks, is both time-consuming and widely service impacting.

contents.text: The traditional method to migrate Internal BGP sessions was strictly limited to reconfiguration of the global configuration ASN and, concurrently, changing all iBGP neighbors' remote ASN from the legacy ASN to the new, permanently retained ASN on each router within the legacy AS. These changes can be challenging to swiftly execute in networks with more than a few dozen internal BGP routers. There are also the concomitant service interruptions as these changes are made to routers within the network, resulting in a reset of iBGP sessions and subsequent route reconvergence to reestablish optimal routing paths. Operators often cannot make such sweeping changes given the associated risks of a highly visible service interruption; rather, they require a more gradual method to migrate Internal BGP sessions, from one ASN to a second, permanently retained ASN, that is not visibly service impacting to its customers.
contents.ja: 内部BGPセッションを移行する従来の方法は、恒久的にASレガシー内の各ルータでASNを保持し、新しいにレガシーASNからすべてのiBGPネイバーのリモートASNを変え、同時に、グローバルコンフィギュレーションASNの再構成に厳密に限られていたと。これらの変更は迅速に超える数十内部BGPルータとネットワークで実行するために挑戦することができます。これらの変化は、最適なルーティング経路を再確立するためにiBGPセッションとその後の経路の再コンバージェンスのリセットをもたらす、ネットワーク内のルータになされるように付随するサービスの中断もあります。オペレータは、しばしば非常に目に見えるサービス中断の関連するリスク所与ような抜本的な変更を行うことができません。むしろ、彼らは永久にそれが顧客に影響を与える目に見えサービスではない、ASNを保持し、1つのASNからの第二に、内部BGPセッションを移行するために、より緩やかな方法を必要としています。

contents.text: With the "Internal BGP AS Migration" mechanism described herein, it allows an Internal BGP speaker to form a single iBGP session using either the old, legacy ASN or the new, permanently retained ASN. The benefits of using this mechanism are several fold. First, it allows for a more gradual and less service-impacting migration away from the legacy ASN to the permanently retained ASN. Second, it (temporarily) permits the coexistence of the legacy and permanently retained ASN within a single network, allowing for uniform BGP path selection among all routers within the consolidated network.
contents.ja: 本明細書中に記載の「移行AS内部BGP」メカニズムを使用すると、それは内部BGPスピーカーが古い、レガシーASNまたは新規のいずれかを使用して、単一のiBGPセッションを形成することを可能にする、永続的にASNを保持しました。このメカニズムを使用する利点は数倍です。まず、それが離れて永続的に保持さASNにレガシーASNからより緩やかと少ないサービスに影響を与えるの移行が可能になります。第二に、それは（一時的に）従来の共存を可能にし、永久的に連結ネットワーク内のすべてのルータの間で均一なBGPパス選択を可能にする、単一のネットワーク内のASNを保持していました。

It is important to recognize that enablement of the "Internal BGP AS Migration" mechanism preserves the semantics of a regular iBGP session (i.e., using identical ASNs). Thus, the BGP attributes transmitted by and the acceptable methods of operation on BGP attributes received from iBGP sessions configured with "Internal BGP AS Migration" capability are no different than those exchanged across an iBGP session without "Internal BGP AS Migration" configured, as defined by [RFC4271] and [RFC4456].

contents.text: Typically, in medium to large networks, BGP Route Reflectors (RRs) [RFC4456] are used to aid in reduction of configuration of iBGP sessions and scalability with respect to overall TCP (and BGP) session maintenance between adjacent iBGP routers. Furthermore, BGP Route Reflectors are typically deployed in pairs within a single Route Reflection cluster to ensure high reliability of the BGP Control Plane. As such, the following example will use Route Reflectors to aid in understanding the use of the "Internal BGP AS Migration" mechanism. Note that Route Reflectors are not a prerequisite to enable "Internal BGP AS Migration" and this mechanism can be enabled independent of the use of Route Reflectors.
contents.ja: 典型的には、大規模なネットワークへの媒体中で、BGPルートリフレクタ（RRS）[RFC4456]は、全体的なTCP（およびBGP）隣接のiBGPルータ間のセッション維持に対するiBGPセッションとスケーラビリティの構成の低減を助けるために使用されています。また、BGPルートリフレクタは、典型的には、BGPコントロールプレーンの高い信頼性を確保するために、1つのルート反射クラスタ内のペアで配置されています。そのため、次の例では、「内部BGP移行AS」メカニズムの使用を理解するのを助けるためにルートリフレクタを使用します。ルートリフレクタは、「移行AS内部BGP」を有効にするには前提条件ではないため、このメカニズムは、ルートリフレクタの使用とは無関係に有効にすることができることに注意してください。

contents.text: The general order of operations is as follows:

contents.text: 1. Within the legacy network, (the routers comprising the set of devices that still have a globally configured legacy ASN), one member of a redundant pair of RRs has its global configuration ASN changed to the permanently retained ASN. Concurrently, the "Internal BGP AS Migration" capability is enabled on all iBGP sessions on that device. contents.text: The benefit of using the aforementioned "Internal BGP AS Migration" capability is that it is a more gradual and less externally service impacting change to accomplish an AS migration. contents.text: This document describes several mechanisms to support ISPs and other organizations that need to perform ASN migrations. Other variations of these mechanisms may exist, for example, in legacy router software that has not been upgraded or reached End of Life, but continues to operate in the network. Such variations are beyond the scope of this document.

contents.text: Companies routinely go through periods of mergers, acquisitions, and divestitures, which in the case of the former cause them to accumulate several legacy ASNs over time. ISPs often do not have control over the configuration of customers' devices (i.e., the ISPs are often not providing a managed CE router service, particularly to medium and large customers that require eBGP). Furthermore, ISPs are using methods to perform ASN migration that do not require coordination with customers. Ultimately, this means there is not a finite period of time after which legacy ASNs will be completely expunged from the ISP's network. In fact, it is common that legacy ASNs and the associated External BGP AS Migration mechanisms discussed in this document can and do persist for several years, if not longer. Thus, it is prudent to plan that legacy ASNs and associated External BGP AS Migration mechanisms will persist in an operational network indefinitely.

contents.text: With respect to the Internal BGP AS Migration mechanism, all of the routers to be consolidated into a single, permanently retained ASN are under the administrative control of a single entity. Thus, completing the migration from iBGP sessions using the legacy ASN to the permanently retained ASN is more straightforward and could be accomplished in a matter of days to months. Finally, good operational hygiene would dictate that it is good practice to avoid using "Internal BGP AS Migration" capability over a long period of time for reasons of not only operational simplicity of the network, but also reduced reliance on that mechanism during the ongoing life cycle management of software, features, and configurations that are maintained on the network.

contents.text: This document discusses a process by which one ASN is migrated into and subsumed by another. This involves manipulating the AS_PATH attribute with the intent of not increasing the AS_PATH length, which would typically cause the BGP route to no longer be selected by BGP's Path Selection Algorithm in others' networks.
